problem.tex: Let $\gamma(t)=e^{it}, 0\leq t\leq2\pi$. (a) Evaluate \[\int_\gamma\frac{\sin z}{z^3}dz.\] (b) Let $f(z)$ be any odd function analytic on a neighborhood of $\overline B_1(0)$. Evaluate \[\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z^3}dz.\]

solution.tex: a) This would be an easy application of Cauchy's integral formula but let's use some more elementary methods to show off. We will show the CIF solution afterwards. Take the Maclaurin expansion of $\sin(z)$, \[\sin(z)=z-\frac{z^3}{3!}+\frac{z^5}{5!}-\cdots.\] Define $p_n(z)$ to be the $n^{th}$ partial sum of this expansion. Then $p_n$ is a polynomial for each $n$ and $p_n\to\sin$ uniformly on compact sets. On $\mathbb{C}^*$, the functions $\frac{p_n(z)}{z^3}$ converge uniformly on compact sets to $f(z)=\frac{\sin(z)}{z^3}$. The functions $\frac{p_n(z)}{z^3}$ are the partial sums of the series \[\frac{1}{z^2}-\frac{1}{3!}+\frac{z^5}{5!}-\cdots.\] Each of these functions has no residue at the origin (vanishing $z^{-1}$ term), so by the residue theorem the integral $\int_\gamma\frac{p_n(z)}{z^3}dz=0$ for each $n$. Then, by uniform convergence on $\gamma$, \[\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z^3}dz=\lim_{n\to\infty}\int_\gamma\frac{p_n(z)}{z^3}dz=0.\] b) see solution to f19f1, it is the same question and the techniques are identical to those above. ps: the CIF version of a) By Cauchy's integral formula, \[\int_\gamma\frac{\sin(z)}{z^3}dz=\frac{2\pi i}{2!}\sin^{(2)}(0).\] How can we tell what $\sin^{(2)}(0)$ is? This depends on what we know about $\sin$. We will rely on the properties that $\sin$ is a solution to the ODE $f''(z)+f(z)=0$ and that $\sin$ is odd. Because $\sin$ is a solution to aforementioned ODE, $\sin^{(2)}(0)=-\sin(0)$. Because $\sin$ is odd, $-\sin(0)=\sin(-0)=\sin(0)$. Therefore $\sin(0)=0$, so $\sin^{(2)}(0)=0$, so the integral $\int_\gamma\frac{\sin(z)}{z^3}dz=0$.
